traffic.translation[0].definitions[0].de: the vehicles moving along a road or street
traffic.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: There wasn’t much traffic on the roads.
The sound of the traffic kept me awake.
traffic.translation[0].definitions[1].de: the movement of aircraft, ships, or trains from one place to another
traffic.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: the problems of air traffic congestion in Europe
traffic.translation[0].definitions[2].de: the movement of people or goods by aircraft, ships, or trains
traffic.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: Most long-distance traffic of heavy goods is done by ships.
traffic.translation[0].definitions[3].de: the secret buying and selling of illegal goods
traffic.translation[0].note_box[0].secti: Sorry I’m late – I was stuck in traffic.
I left early, hoping to miss the traffic.
The congestion charge did cut road traffic in central London.
At last the traffic was moving again.
Traffic was diverted onto the A166 as emergency services cleared the wreckage
We ran into heavy traffic near the airport.
The traffic is fairly light at this time of day.
The traffic was terrible this morning.
Traffic’s very slow going out of New York.
I left early to try to miss the rush-hour traffic.
There is quite a lot of local traffic.
As motorway traffic worsens, commuters may have to find other ways of getting to and from work.
The driver, too busy watching oncoming traffic, doesn’t notice the pedestrian ahead.
She spent two hours sitting in a traffic jam.
The road widening should help to improve traffic flow.
He’s been involved in a traffic accident.
The teenagers got stopped by the local traffic police.
You get a lot of traffic noise living here.
The new ring road will reduce the volume of traffic through the village.
There was a constant stream of traffic.
The only noise was the distant rumble of traffic on the coastal road.
traffic.translation[1].definitions[0].de: to take someone to another country and force them to work, for example as a prostitute
traffic.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: He had made a fortune by trafficking young women.
traffic.translation[2].definitions[0].de: the movement of planes, ships, trains etc from one place to another
traffic.translation[2].definitions[0].ex: a telecommunications network for controllingair traffic.
traffic.translation[2].definitions[1].de: the movement of people or goods by air, ship, train etc
traffic.translation[2].definitions[1].ex: The airline saidpassenger traffic dropped 29% in February.
the extensive traffic of Chinese goods to Canada
traffic.translation[2].definitions[2].de: the movement of computer DATA or other electronic information from one place to another
traffic.translation[2].definitions[2].ex: The three companies now control 90% of the nation’sphone traffic.
a digital service used fordata traffic
traffic.translation[2].definitions[3].de: the number of people buying a particular product or using a particular service
traffic.translation[2].definitions[3].ex: If consumer spending picks up, there will be keen competition forconsumer traffic.
